title: 10 Classic Recipes You Will Need For 2025 Thanksgiving Dinner
review_html:
As soon as Halloween is behind us, thereâ€™s only one thing on everyoneâ€™s mind: whatâ€™s going on the Thanksgiving table. This holiday may come just once a year (well, twice if you count the endless leftovers), but nothing beats the comfort of a traditional Thanksgiving feast. From a perfectly roasted turkey and buttery stuffing to mashed potatoes swimming in gravy, the classics never fail. And of course, dessert is non-negotiableâ€”think pumpkin pie, pecan pie cheesecake, and all the sweet treats that make the day complete. So get ready to gather, indulge, and maybe even sneak in a post-turkey nap, because these 10Â must-try Thanksgiving recipes are here to make your holiday unforgettable.

1. Crisp-Skinned Butterflied Roast Turkey With Gravy

Our butterflied (spatchcocked) turkey recipe keeps things simple with a dry brineâ€”just rub kosher salt all over the bird and let it rest in the fridge overnight. By removing the backbone with poultry shears (trust us, itâ€™s easier than it sounds!), the turkey cooks more quickly and evenly, giving you perfectly juicy meat. And donâ€™t toss that backbone! Itâ€™s packed with cartilage and flavor, making it the perfect base for a rich, hearty gravy.

2. Basic Cranberry Sauce

There are endless cranberry sauce recipes out there, but if youâ€™re after something classic, easy, and traditional (without resorting to the can), this is the one. All it takes is fresh cranberries, sugar, water, and a pinch of salt, with a splash of orange juice to brighten the tartness and give it a perfectly balanced flavor.

3. Classic Sage and Sausage Stuffing (or Dressing)

For me, Thanksgiving is all about the stuffingâ€”moist, fluffy, and packed with flavor. This version is loaded with sage, juicy bites of sausage, and just the right amount of garlic, plus tender celery and onion for that classic balance. A whole stick of butter gives it rich depth (and yes, itâ€™s absolutely worth it). And if by some miracle you have leftovers, try pressing them into a waffle ironâ€”stuffing waffles are the ultimate day-after-Thanksgiving treat.

4.Â The Ultimate Homemade Green Bean Casserole

The canned-soup shortcut works in a pinch, but if youâ€™re craving nostalgia and great flavor, the from-scratch route is the way to go. Think crisp, freshly blanched green beans, a creamy mushroom sauce made with real mushrooms, and crispy fried shallots you make yourself.

5. Â The Best Roasted Sweet Potatoes

Sweet potatoes deserve to shine, but too often they turn out bland or starchy. The secret here is a quick par-cook: simmering the potatoes in water between 135 and 170Â°F (57â€“77Â°C) before roasting. At this temperature, an enzyme kicks in that transforms starch into maltose, giving the potatoes natural sweetness and incredible flavor. From there, a short roast delivers those irresistible crisp, caramelized edges.

And the best part? You only need a handful of ingredientsâ€”sweet potatoes, olive oil, salt, pepper, plus a touch of honey and parsleyâ€”for a side dish thatâ€™s as simple as it is delicious.

6. Â Easy Roasted Brussels Sprouts

If youâ€™re still steaming or boiling Brussels sprouts, itâ€™s time for an upgrade. Hereâ€™s all it takes: trim and halve the sprouts, toss them with olive oil, salt, and pepper, roast until golden and crisp, and serve. Thatâ€™s itâ€”simple, effortless, and incredibly tasty. Plus, you can say goodbye to any sulfur-y fridge smells from leftovers.

7. Â Ultra-Fluffy Mashed Potatoes

Perfectly fluffy mashed potatoes come down to one key step: minimizing starch. Start by peeling and dicing russets, then rinse them well in cold water before boiling until tender. Give them another rinse to wash away any lingering starch, then run them through a ricer or food mill. The right tool makes all the differenceâ€”unlike a blender or food processor, these wonâ€™t overwork the potatoes, keeping your mash smooth, airy, and light.

8. Â Butternut Pumpkin Pie

Fun fact: that â€œpumpkinâ€ purÃ©e in the can? Itâ€™s almost always butternut squashâ€”and honestly, thatâ€™s a win. Squash packs a deeper, sweeter flavor and is far easier to work with than true pumpkin.

Stellaâ€™s butternut pie shows off just how good it can be: roasted squash blended with homemade condensed milk, brown sugar, vanilla, and plenty of warm spice. The result? A silky, fragrant filling that beats old-school pumpkin any day.

And if from-scratch feels like too much, canned squash still makes a pie thatâ€™s rich, creamy, and crowd-pleasingâ€”no apologies needed.

9. Â Classic Pecan Pie

No Thanksgiving dessert table is complete without a classic pecan pie. This version keeps things sweet and balanced with a blend of honey, corn syrup, and brown sugar, while vanilla and a pinch of salt round out the flavor. Toasted pecans bring that signature nutty crunch, and blind-baking the crust ensures it stays crisp beneath the rich, custardy filling. The end result? A pie thatâ€™s equal parts smooth, crunchy, and irresistible.

10. Perfect Gravy

Homemade gravy is the ultimate holiday essential, whether youâ€™re pouring it over juicy turkey, creamy mashed potatoes, or warm, buttery biscuits. Because it plays such a central role on the table, it has to be flawlessâ€”and this recipe delivers just that.

Cook Your Thanksgiving Dinner with Tasty

What's that? You want even more traditional Thanksgiving dishes? It's cool, we've got you covered. Check out Tasty for complete listing of Thanksgiving recipes for an overflowing cornucopia of turkeys, pies, stuffings, mashed potatoes, and more.
